I have received countless messages from my constituents, who are concerned and outraged over the actions of the Trump Administration during the first month of their tenure. I share your concerns and am strongly opposed to recent decisions that endanger our national security and contradict our Nation’s core values. I have taken several steps to oppose these actions by President Trump, and have compiled an update on my website. One of the most concerning issues to date is the secrecy surrounding the Administration’s relationship with Russia. The intelligence community’s December 2016 conclusion that Russia had interfered with U.S. elections is disconcerting and alarming. In response, I have cosponsored H.R. 530, the SECURE Our Democracy Act and H.R. 356, the Protecting Our Democracy Act. H.R. 530 would sanction any foreign entity that has interfered in federal elections while H.R. 356 would create an independent commission to investigate attempts to influence the 2016 election by Russia.   Additionally, reports of discussions between Russian officials and Administration transition team are particularly troubling, and raise questions about potential violations by Gen. Flynn of the Logan Act. Though Gen. Flynn resigned from the post of National Security Advisor, his actions deserve closer scrutiny and oversight which is why I have asked Chairman Royce of the Foreign Affairs Committee to demand that Gen. Flynn testify before the Committee on the nature of his relationship with Russia. As a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, I will continue to monitor the situation and feel it is my duty to push for transparency and accountability for the American people.  http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration

Steve Bannon’s seemingly unchecked influence as an advisor to President Trump is also of great concern. I find his appointment to a high position in the White House disturbing, given his history of anti-Semitic, xenophobic and racist rhetoric. Last fall, I sent a letter to the President urging him to reconsider Bannon’s appointment in an effort to diversify his staff and create an administration that is inclusive and represents our core American values. Instead, President Trump has raised Bannon’s position within the Administration by appointing him to the National Security Council (NSC) while removing critical officers from the Principals Committee, such as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Director of National Intelligence. I informed the President of my concern that Mr. Bannon’s appointment puts American lives at stake and urged him to reconsider the politicization of the NSC.  In addition, I have cosponsored H.R. 804, the Protect the National Security Council from Political Interference Act of 2017, which bars the President from appointing aides to the NSC. http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration

Over the past few weeks, President Trump has signed multiple executive orders that support divisive and destructive policies.  The President’s January 25th Executive Order directing the Administration to build a wall between the U.S. and Mexico will not only cost taxpayers billions of dollars, but will accomplish nothing in the way of reforming our broken immigration system and strain our security and business relations with Mexico.  The Executive Order on Sanctuary Cities threatens critical law enforcement funding and is counterproductive to improving national security.  I cosponsored H.R. 748, the Safeguarding Sanctuary Cities Act which would ensure that no federal funds are withheld from state or localities that choose to not comply with a voluntary immigration detainer request.  Furthermore, Trump’s executive orders suspending refugee resettlement and changing immigration policies for certain Muslim-majority countries contradict the very ideas of inclusion that America was founded on and discriminate unfairly against Muslims who are desperately trying to escape from life threatening conflicts.  Though the President’s order has been temporarily stayed by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, I have cosponsored H.R. 724, the SOLVE Act.  This legislation would nullify President Trump’s executive order on all refugees and the restrictions on those seven Muslim-majority countries. http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration

The fact that President Trump consistently refuses to release his tax returns and fully divest himself of his vast business portfolio also proves troubling for many of my constituents. I share your concerns and have cosponsored H.R. 371, the Presidential Conflicts of Interest Act.  This legislation would require the President and Vice President to disclose and divest any potential financial conflicts of interest, lending greater transparency to an Administration that has been shrouded in confusion and controversy. This bill would also require Presidential appointees to recuse themselves from matters involving their agencies and the President’s potential financial conflict of interests. http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration

Since the beginning of the 115th Congress, President Trump and Republicans have expressed their intent to repeal the Affordable Care Act and defund Planned Parenthood. Over 20 million Americans who have gained coverage thanks to the ACA would essentially be left helpless and there would be devastating impacts on women’s health care. Defunding Planned Parenthood would make services such as preventative screenings, tests, and contraceptive services even more inaccessible, particularly in medically underserved areas. This is unacceptable and I urged the President to reconsider his support for efforts to repeal the ACA and defund Planned Parenthood. I have also sent a letter to Speaker Ryan expressing my concerns about the recent efforts to undermine Title X family planning funds. This week the House voted on H.J.Res.43 which would roll back Title X, and while I voted against it, H.J.Res.43 unfortunately passed the House of Representatives. http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration

Tonight, I will listen to President Trump as he delivers his first address to a Joint Session of Congress. Since his inauguration I have heard many concerns and worries from constituents about the President’s actions. Over the course of the first 40 days of his Presidency, President Trump has attacked affordable healthcare coverage for working families, tried to institute an ill-conceived Muslim ban, failed to address the growing acts of anti-Semitism across the country, tied the hands of Department of Veterans of Affairs from providing the best care to our Nation’s veterans, threatened our public education system, begun the rollback of important consumer protections that were instituted in the aftermath of the Great Recession, and threatened our First Amendment.   As the Eighth District’s representative, I will not stand idly by as the President and the Republican Congress recklessly repeal laws that my constituents and I fought hard for over the past decade. Rather than using tonight’s speech to highlight what divides us, I hope that President Trump will use this opportunity to focus on our Nation’s problems that we can tackle together. Follow me on twitter today to read more about my reaction to President Trump’s first 40 days in office: @RepSires. You can also read my official response to many of the Trump Administration’s actions thus far at: http://sires.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-sires-response-to-the-actions-of-the-new-administration.

As the Peace Corps celebrates its 56th birthday today, I am proud to introduce the Respect for Peace Corps Volunteers Act with my colleague Rep. David Young (R-IA). This bill would afford former volunteers and staff members the dignity of using the name and logo of the Peace Corps on tombstones and in obituaries. On April 22nd, I had the honor of visiting the World War II Sicily–Rome American Cemetery and Memorial in Nettuno, Italy as a part of a congressional delegation. This site was founded as a temporary war cemetery just two days after the Battle of Anzio in January 1944. Now, 73 years later, it has been enshrined as a beautiful memorial to the American lives lost in Italy during the war. The Battle of Anzio was a pivotal military operation that would lead to the liberation of Rome and the eventual victory of Allied forces. These men never knew how monumental their sacrifice would be. The Sicily-Rome American Cemetery and Memorial is one of the 25 American military cemeteries in foreign countries around the world, which include sites honoring the fallen from other critical battles such as the Invasion of Normandy and the Battle of the Atlantic. During National Military Appreciation Month, and as Memorial Day approaches, the image of over 7,800 Americans buried in Italy will stay with me, and I encourage everyone to take time and reflect on the cost that so many have paid for our freedom.
